abstract: Ornithologists and amateur birders alike have long wrestled with the historical nature of bird names bestowed by early collectors.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 1, the American Ornithological Society announced that it would be renaming all the birds under its purview that are currently named for human beings. The birds’ new names will reflect the species’ appearance or habitat — some trait associated with the actual bird, in other words, and not with the colonial explorer who first identified it.
headline: North American Birds Will No Longer Be Named for Racists — or Anybody Else
keywords: Birds;Birdwatching;Names, Organizational;Audubon, John James;Discrimination;Confederate States of America;American Ornithological Society;Race and Ethnicity

abstract: Millions of U.S. drug users now are addicted to several substances, not just opioids like fentanyl and heroin. The shift is making treatment far more difficult.

Discarded red plastic cups. A wet sock flung over a bush. A carpet square. And scattered across the forest floor: orange vial caps and used syringes.
headline: ‘A Monster’: Super Meth and Other Drugs Push Crisis Beyond Opioids

abstract: What’s the difference between influenza A and influenza B, and does it matter which you catch?

abstract: As the Biden administration prepares to toughen air quality standards, health benefits are weighed against the cost of compliance.

abstract: Once a hope for the future of Israel and the Palestinians, “the two-state solution” can now feel like a hollow phrase.
lead_paragraph: In the decades-long effort to resolve the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians, it has seemed to many like the least flawed among many imperfect ideas: the two-state solution. It would create an independent Palestinian state, made up of Gaza and the West Bank, that would exist alongside Israel. The goal has become official policy of most governments around the world and has been the basis for peace talks for years.

abstract: Aprons for a good cause, a roasting pan for the holiday bird and more food news.
lead_paragraph: Not enough Thanksgiving guests for a 12 to 16 pounder? There are other avian options to bronze in the oven and present with panache. There’s guinea fowl (above), a pasture-raised bird with luscious dark meat that’s not gamy, which is as easy to roast as a chicken. Season the interior with salt and pepper, tuck in a bunch of fresh herbs, rub the outside with butter, oil or duck fat, set it on a rack at 375 degrees and roast a large one, four pounds or so to serve six, for an hour and 20 minutes. You’ll only need about an hour for a 2- to 3-pounder serving two to four. Heritage Foods has 4- to 4.5-pound guinea hens raised by the Good Shepherd Poultry Ranch Network based in Kansas. D’Artagnan sells 2 to 3 pound hens from California.
headline: Turkey Potpie, Guinea Fowl and a Hybrid Turnip for the Thanksgiving Table
keywords: Thanksgiving Day;Poultry;Cookware;Cooking and Cookbooks;Food

lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has pulled back on plans to announce the conclusion of substantial portions of a new Asian-Pacific trade pact at an international meeting in San Francisco this week, after several top Democratic lawmakers threatened to oppose the deal, people familiar with the matter said.
headline: Biden’s Pacific Trade Pact Suffers Setback After Criticism From Congress

abstract: The former president’s Veterans Day speech used language similar to the dehumanizing rhetoric wielded by dictators like Hitler and Mussolini.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign rejected criticism that he was echoing the language of fascist dictators with his vow to root out his political opponents like “vermin,” then doubled down: It said on Monday that the “sad, miserable existence” of those who made such comparisons would be “crushed” with Mr. Trump back in the White House.
headline: After Calling Foes ‘Vermin,’ Trump Campaign Warns Its Critics Will Be ‘Crushed’
keywords: Trump, Donald J;Presidential Election of 2024;United States Politics and Government;Fringe Groups and Movements;Republican Party

abstract: The messages urge the Biden administration to press Israel for a cease-fire, according to U.S. officials. Two were said to have been sent in the first week of the war.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of State Department employees have signed internal memos to Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken expressing serious disagreement with the Biden administration’s approach to Israel’s military campaign in Gaza, according to U.S. officials, part of a surging tide of internal disagreement within the Biden administration over the Middle East crisis.
headline: State Department employees send Blinken ‘dissent’ cables over Gaza policy.
keywords: Gaza Strip;Israel;Middle East;United States;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Blinken, Antony J;Netanyahu, Benjamin;Hamas;State Department;Israel-Gaza War (2023- );United States Politics and Government

abstract: After an acting career that included playing the Olympic sprinter Wilma Rudolph in a TV movie, she became known as a director for her work at regional theaters.
lead_paragraph: Shirley Jo Finney, an actor who became a prolific and award-winning director of plays that dug deeply into the Black experience, died on Oct. 10 in Bellingham, Wash. She was 74.
headline: Shirley Jo Finney, 74, Dies; Addressed the Black Experience Onstage
keywords: Finney, Shirley Jo (1949-2023);Deaths (Obituaries);Theater;Black People;Blacks;Television;Actors and Actresses

abstract: The Army acknowledged that the Buffalo Soldiers, 19 of whom were hanged, had been convicted in military trials that were tainted by racial discrimination.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 11, 1917, Pfc. Thomas C. Hawkins and 12 other Black soldiers who had been convicted of mutiny and other crimes during a riot in Houston earlier that year were hanged. It was the single largest mass execution of American soldiers by the Army.
headline: Army Overturns Convictions of 110 Black Soldiers Charged in 1917 Riot
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces;Discrimination;Race and Ethnicity;False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments;Courts-Martial;Houston (Tex);United States Army

abstract: Also, the Supreme Court adopts an ethics code. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces advanced today to the gates of Gaza’s largest hospital, where doctors describe a dire situation: Fuel, medicine and food are running out for hundreds of patients and thousands of others sheltering.
headline: Israeli Forces Reached Gaza’s Main Hospital

abstract: The lack of fuel, used to operate the fork lifts that unload the goods and the trucks that deliver them, is imperiling the only lifeline for the 2.2 million people in the coastal enclave.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations said on Monday that its already dwindling reserve of fuel in the Gaza Strip would run out as soon as Tuesday, preventing the organization from receiving and distributing the desperately needed aid trickling in, and imperiling the only lifeline for the 2.2 million people in the coastal enclave.
headline: U.N. says that without fuel it can no longer distribute humanitarian aid.
keywords: Guterres, Antonio;Gaza Strip;Israel;Egypt;Hamas;United Nations Relief and Works Agency;United Nations;Israel-Gaza War (2023- )

abstract: The House could take up the proposal as early as Tuesday. With growing opposition from House Republicans, it will need Democrats’ backing.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson’s proposal to avert a government shutdown at the end of the week ran into increasing opposition on Monday from hard-line Republicans. But with Democratic opposition softening, it appeared the plan could be headed toward bipartisan approval within days.
headline: Democrats Signal Openness to Plan to Avert Shutdown as Republicans Balk
keywords: United States Politics and Government;Federal Budget (US);Shutdowns (Institutional);Democratic Party;House of Representatives;Republican Party;Senate;Johnson, Mike (1972- )

abstract: With hundreds living outdoors and temperatures plummeting, Alaska’s largest city is struggling to halt a rising death toll among homeless residents.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of frigid temperatures and heavy snow in recent days has contributed to a spate of deaths of homeless people in Anchorage, Alaska, adding to a toll that had already left political leaders scrambling for new solutions.
headline: An ‘Unimaginable’ Death Toll Among Anchorage’s Homeless Residents
keywords: Deaths (Fatalities);Homeless Persons;Cold and Cold Spells;ANCHORAGE (ALASKA);ALASKA

abstract: The astronauts lost track of the bag while performing maintenance outside the International Space Station this month. Now it’s floating in space.
lead_paragraph: Lost: One tool bag. Last seen this month floating through space near the International Space Station. If found, please return to NASA.
headline: Two Astronauts Lost a Tool Bag in Space. It’s Not Alone.
